title: Strategic Framework for Hotdog-Sandwich Classification Consensus

prerequisites: Identify and recruit key stakeholder representatives
steps.outcome: Create a legitimate, multi-stakeholder body to develop classification standards
risks: Difficulty in getting buy-in from all key groups
Potential for the council to become politicized

prerequisites: Gather input from stakeholders on structural, cultural, and practical considerations
Review historical precedents and existing classification schemes
steps.outcome: Establish a classification system that recognizes both structural and cultural dimensions of hotdogs and sandwiches
risks: Difficulty in reconciling conflicting stakeholder perspectives
Potential for the framework to be seen as overly complex

prerequisites: Define clear criteria and procedures for classifying new or ambiguous food items
Establish mechanisms for stakeholder input and appeals
steps.outcome: Create a flexible, responsive system that can adapt to evolving culinary trends and innovations
risks: Potential for the process to be seen as arbitrary or inconsistent
Difficulty in enforcing the classification standards

prerequisites: Engage with media outlets and influencers
steps.outcome: Increase public understanding and acceptance of the classification framework
risks: Difficulty in reaching and convincing skeptical segments of the population
Potential for misinformation and conspiracy theories to undermine the campaign

steps.outcome: Provide a structured process for addressing disagreements and preventing escalation
risks: Difficulty in getting all stakeholders to agree to the dispute resolution process
Potential for the mechanism to be seen as biased or ineffective

resource_requirements: Funding for the Hotdog-Sandwich Classification Council
Expertise in food science, culinary history, linguistics, and conflict resolution
Effective communication and public engagement capabilities
Commitment and buy-in from key stakeholder groups
